Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds David Hamilton Case of the California Institute of Technology to conduct a research project in Geosciences during the summer of 2013 at the Japan Agency for Marine-Earth Science and Technology (JAMSTEC) in Kochi, Japan. The project title is "Understanding Which Microbial Species Live Below the Seafloor and What They Eat." The host scientist is Dr. Fumio Inagaki.

Marine mud volcanoes are hydrocarbon-rich areas where sediment is moved upward from deep within Earth's oceanic crust to the seafloor. Samples taken from the top of a marine mud volcano (i.e., the seafloor) are often assumed to be representative of geochemical and biological conditions deep within the oceanic crust (i.e., 100s of meters below the seafloor). This study directly tests this assumption by recovering biological samples from the top of a marine mud volcano and 115 meters below the ocean floor. Starting in 2012 biological samples were incubated with stable isotope-labeled food sources (e.g. 13C-methane, 13C-glucose, 15N-ammonium) for one year. Following incubation and with the assistance of EAPSI 2013 support microbiological cells are (1) identified by phylogeny and (2) analyzed for isotopic content to determine which cells consumed which food sources. This informs the identity and metabolic function of microbial communities in Earth's subsurface and tests the assumption that the top and bottom of marine mud volcanoes contain identical conditions.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, society will benefit by increased knowledge of the microbial controls on geochemistry in a hydrocarbon-rich environment which has been proposed as a potential untapped source of natural gas. Additionally, the Fellow is involved in teaching K-12 science through activities, lessons, and talks. Sharing stories, photographs, and excitement for science with a young audience promotes teaching, training, learning, and inspiration of future generations of scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award provided funding for an American PhD student to spend 10 weeks conducting scientific research in Japan. The topic of research was microbial activity in a submarine mud volcano. Mud volcanoes are geological features which bring fluid and mud from deep within the Earth toward the surface. Thus, if samples are taken from the top of a mud volcano they are often assumed to represent the chemical and biological conditions deep within the Earth. For this reason, mud volcanoes are worth research investment because they represent a relatively easy way to explore the extreme limits of life on our planet (i.e., how deep in the planet life can persist). Mud volcanoes are worth studying for a second reason, as well. They are often rich in methane, a common fuel source and also a greenhouse gas. It is known that communities of microorganisms live within mud volcanoes and both produce and consume methane as a food source, but the specific mechanisms and rates of production/consumption remain unclear. Thus, studying these microbes can inform biological methane cycling. This is useful in two ways: first, if we as a society want to harness methane from mud volcanoes as our own energy source, it is important to know what biological mechanisms already exist for creating and degrading methane. Second, if we desire to consume methane which already exists in the atmosphere as a greenhouse gas, there is much to learn from biological organisms which already perform methane consumption.

It was hypothesized that the metabolisms of microorganisms in a mud volcano off the coast of Japan would be relatively fast, because the environment is rich in the microbial food source -- methane. However, experiments funded by this award showed that in fact the microorganisms produce and consume methane at very low rates. In fact, in only one experimental condition was methane production observed. In this experiment, it's possible organic matter was fermented by indigenous bacteria, producing carbon dioxide in the mud volcano. The carbon dioxide may have then been converted back to methane by a second species of microorganism. However, this somewhat convoluted pathway remains strictly a hypothesis and more investigation is required.

The EAPSI 2013 funding provided a professional advancement opportunity to a young career scientist. In addition to working closely with one laboratory in Japan, the awardee was able to travel to other laboratories in Japan. These visits established new professional connections as well as furthering pre-existing connections. The professional ties forged and strengthened will be beneficial to the student's career, as well as foster a continued relationship between the US and Japan.
